Actually, people sitting there doing the maths at desks. There were buildings full of them, copying numbers from ledgers to ledger and running calculations by hand. Companies that go all in on AI will have cost structures that are absurdly lower than companies still using humans. You're not paying salaries, benefits, office space, HR overhead. You're just paying for compute and electricity. A company with 500 employees spending $50 million per year on labor could do the same work with AI for maybe $2 or3 million in cloud costs. The competitive dynamic is brutal. Two companies selling the same product. One uses AI for everything it can and still uses mostly humans. The AI company can undercut on price by maybe 30 to 40% and still have higher margins. The human run company can't compete. they either switch to AI or they die. And this forcing function is what drives adoption. Companies won't move to AI because they want to be innovative or because they care about efficiency. They'll move to AI because competitors who move first are eating their lunch. And I think the timeline on this is faster than people think. Elon says there's a lot of inertia. Within 10 years, robotic surgeons will make the cost of surgery plummet dramatically while expanding access to quality health care worldwide. This is astonishing. The cost structure for surgery today is insane. A cardiac surgeon in the US makes around $400,000 per year. They work maybe 50 to 60 hours per week. They need years of training, four years of med school, 5 years of residency, two to three years of fellowship. By the time they're actually practicing, they're in their mid-30s and carrying hundreds of thousands worth of student debt. Now, compare that to an Optimus robot. It's predicted to cost around $20,000 to manufacture at scale. It can operate 24/7 at roughly three bucks an hour in electricity and maintenance costs. No salary, no benefits, no malpractice, no insurance, no vacation days. But the real advantage is the shared memory system. Every human surgeon builds experience one case at a time over decades. An Optimus surgeon has instant access to every surgery ever performed by every other Optimus robot worldwide and huge amounts of training data from surgeons as well. A human surgeon might do 300 heart surgeries in their career. An Optimus surgeon effectively has done millions before it even starts. It can see an infrared and ultraviolet. It's got extreme precision. It never had too much caffeine or got into a fight with its spouse or worked a 14-hour shift. The experience gap becomes massive within months of deployment. When robots can handle that end to end, you're looking at a gigantic cut in costs. That $100,000 today could end up being around $10,000 for example. And that's assuming hospitals keep their current markup structure. Competition could even drive that lower.
